Carson Bailey
AboutResearch

Research

My general research interests are centered in Young Adult literature (particularly fantasy and science fiction) and popular culture. Understanding the cultural rhetoric surrounding popular texts geared towards younger audiences allows us to garner deeper insights about our culture, values, global and national political climates, and more. My undergraduate honors thesis, Last [Disempowered Person] Standing: Identity in the Battle Royale Narrative Formula traces the phenomenon of the battle royale in history and popular culture. My current masters thesis, Cyborgs, Wolves, and Aliens, Oh My: Marissa Meyer’s The Lunar Chronicles Goes to Outer Space to Make Space for Inclusive and Diverse YA Fairy Tale Retellings looks at Young Adult fantasy and science fiction fairy tale retellings that reflect cultural shifts in the demands for increased representation of inclusive and diverse characters, settings, identities, and more.

Last [Disempowered Person] Standing: Identity in the Battle Royale Narrative Formula

The Japanese film Battle Royale established an internationally popular narrative formula that found its origins in the horrors of American slavery. Many authors transformed the savagery of the antebellum tradition into a fictional narrative formula that explores tensions between the haves and have-nots of the contemporary world. Partaking of elements from science-fiction and horror, the battle-royale narrative formula depicts a sole-survivor competition sponsored by the elite, which exploits marginalized contestants. This narrative formula is most often marketed to adolescents, who are themselves marginalized by virtue of the liminal space they inhabit between childhood and adulthood. As a result, identity and the formation of identity as it connects to marginalized populations are central issues in battle-royale texts. I investigate this by drawing on intersections between cultural studies, race studies, and gender and sexuality studies. In my introduction I discuss the cultural phenomenon of the battle-royale narrative formula, looking at reality television shows such as Survivor and video games such as Fortnite to establish the formula’s mass success in popular culture. My first chapter highlights the connections between the historical phenomenon and nascent examples of the formula, beginning with Ralph Ellison’s “Battle Royal” and developing through William Golding’s Lord of the Flies, and Stephen King’s The Long Walk. In subsequent chapters I examine a range of texts, including Suzanne Collins’ series The Hunger Games,Gerard McMurray’s film The First Purge, Libba Bray’s Beauty Queens,Greg McLean’s The Belko Experiment, and Koushon Takami’s novel and film Battle Royale. My conclusion focuses on how issues of identity and marginalization continue to resonate with adolescent audiences. I hope to add chapters on drag ballroom culture, battle royale style video games, sports as battle royales, and reality television battle royales.
